title: Building Lovable: $10M ARR in 60 days with 15 people | Anton Osika (CEO and co-founder)
themes: Future of programming and engineering roles
key_insights: Spend a full week using AI tools to solve a real problem to reach top 1% proficiency globally
Hire generalists with deep expertise in one area plus obsessive care about the product and team
Being extremely specific in AI prompts is more critical than with human communication
Product-market fit can drive 1M+ ARR growth per week with minimal team size (18 people)
The biggest bottleneck shifts from engineering to understanding what users actually want
Work trials (1 day to 1 week) are essential for vetting candidates in high-growth environments
Building in-office with shared lunches enables high-bandwidth communication and faster iteration
topics_discussed: Live demo of building an Airbnb clone in minutes
Scaling from 4M to 10M ARR in 60 days with 15 people
AI agent getting 'stuck' and technical solutions
European vs Silicon Valley startup culture
Using Linear and FigJam for operations
Future of engineering roles and required skills
Importance of being specific with AI prompts
Origin story from GPT Engineer open source project
Supporting entrepreneurs after initial product build
memorable_quotes: We're building the last piece of software
People love the product. That's the driver of the growth.

Being a generalist, I think much more important than it used to be. If I'm putting together a product team today, I would really obsess about getting as many skill sets as possible for each person I hire.
frameworks_mentioned: Minimum Lovable Product (MLP) instead of MVP
Scaling laws for AI system improvement
recommended_for: Anyone interested in the future of software development
summary: Anton Osika shares how Lovable became Europe's fastest-growing startup by enabling non-technical users to build software through AI, reaching 10M ARR in 60 days with just 15 people. The conversation covers practical insights on AI tool mastery, hiring exceptional talent, and the fundamental shift from engineering as the bottleneck to product discovery and user understanding.
